ZnGA/DMC catalysts for the synthesis of high molecular weight poly(propylene carbonate): The crucial role of water treatment Yulong Wu Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Conceptualization Yingfang Nie Methodology Li Sun Validation ZhenHao Xi Writing – review & editing Resources ⁎ Zhen Liu Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200237, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200237, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Zinc glutarate (ZnGA) is a prominent catalyst for the production of CO2-based poly(propylene carbonate). The original catalysts, ZnO-GA (Cat 1) and ZnAc2-GA (Cat 3), were prepared using ZnO and ZnAc2 as Zn sources, respectively. ZnO-GA-H2O (Cat 2) and ZnAc2-GA-H2O (Cat 4) were prepared by water treatment of Cat 1 and Cat 3, respectively. After water treatment, both Cat 2 and Cat 4 showed enhanced performance for copolymerization of CO2 and propylene oxide. The characterizations demonstrated that H2O is a critical component that not only improves the crystallinity and external surface area of ZnGA, but also increases the number of surface Zn-OH groups. By adding a portion of cyanide, further modification on Cat 4 resulted in a group of ZnAc2-GA-H2O/DMC catalysts (m-Cat 4). The polymerization reached a high yield of 1729 g poly/g Cat and a selectivity of 98.7 % at molar ratio of DMC/ZnGA = 1: 10 (t = 24 h; T = 70 °C; P = 4 MPa). The modified ZnGA/DMC catalyst exhibited remarkable yield and selectivity for the copolymerization of CO2 and propylene oxide to produce high molecular weight alternating copolymers (2.3 × 105 g/mol). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 Zinc glutarate Copolymerization Poly(propylene carbonate) Propylene oxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO2 emissions from the combustion of fossil fuels are the primary cause of global warming and climate change [1]. Meanwhile, CO2 is a nontoxic, stable, inexpensive, abundant, and non-flammable C1 feedstock. As such, there is interest in utilizing CO2 to make commercial products [2,3]. Poly(propylene carbonate) (PPC) can be produced by the ring-opening copolymerization (ROCOP) of CO2 and propylene oxide. It has superior properties, such as high strength, durability, transparency, and electrical insulation, etc. Currently, CO2-based PPC has already been used in various applications, including electronics, optical media, the automotive industry, and the medical industry, etc. [4]. The first ROCOP of CO2 and propylene oxide (PO) was carried out by Inoue in 1969 [5]. Since then, numerous heterogeneous catalyst systems, such as zinc dicarboxylates, double metal cyanides, and rare earth ternary catalysts, and homogeneous catalyst systems, such as Salen-metal complexes and zinc phenoxides, have been developed. Inevitably, most of the catalysts have failed to meet the following two characteristics: i) to produce a perfect alternating copolymer with a high catalytic performance, and ii) to achieve high yield and selectivity with a lower content of ether linkages in the polymer chain and a lower ratio of cyclic carbonate by-product [6]. The current challenge is to develop catalysts that not only exhibit high yield and selectivity but also produce high molecular weight alternating copolymers. ZnGA is a typical heterogeneous catalyst for CO2 and PO copolymerization. It is a widely used catalyst due to its simple synthesis process, and produces PPC with high molecular weight, and high carbonate linkage content [7]. However, the performance of the catalyst synthesized using different Zn and acid sources has not been satisfactory. In 1981, Soga et al. investigated a series of zinc-based catalysts prepared from various aliphatic dicarboxylic acids and Zn(OH)2, and concluded that the best combination for the synthesis of the catalyst is Zn(OH)2 with glutaric acid (GA) [8]. Darensbourg et al. reported the white precipitate of ZnGA with a low yield by adding dicarboxylic acid to a heated toluene solution of zinc oxide [9]. Ree et al. synthesized ZnGA catalysts using different zinc sources. [7] The ZnGA synthesized with zinc oxide (ZnO) and GA was found to have a high catalytic performance, which was mainly attributed to the morphological structure of ZnGA. The effects of crystallinity, crystallization quality, and external surface area have been discussed in detail [10]. Although ZnO is most suitable for the synthesis of ZnGA, several studies have reported that ZnGA synthesized from ZnAc2–2H2O showed satisfactory yield and product properties [10–13]. However, ZnGA synthesized from anhydrous zinc acid (ZnAc2) and GA showed almost no production. The molecular structure of zinc glutarate has been identified as having a unique conformation in which the Zn ion centers coordinate with four carboxyl oxygen atoms from different glutarate ligands, forming a distorted tetrahedral geometry [14]. There is a close relationship between the structure and the performance of the catalyst. Experimental and theoretical studies have shown that the intrinsic structure of Zn-dicarboxylic acid is the main reason why its performance cannot be substantially increased, and the optimum distance between Zn-Zn is 4.3 – 5.0 Å [15]. Compared with CO2, PO was found to be more readily adsorbed onto the ZnGA catalyst and inserted into the Zn-O bond, suggesting that the ZnGA-catalyzed CO2/PO ROCOP was initiated by PO rather than CO2 [16]. The catalytic performance of ZnGA was enhanced by increasing the content of the Zn-OH groups, which can act as active initiating species [17]. Although modifications focus on improving catalytic performance and producing alternating copolymers with high molecular weight, high glass transition temperature, and excellent thermal stability, these attempts have not been satisfactory so far. The low catalytic performance has limited the use of ZnGA in industry [13]. Various attempts have been made to improve the catalytic performance of ZnGA. A number of operations failed to improve the catalyst performance, such as changing the stirring method [18], using montmorillonite as a support in ZnGA catalyst [19], introducing ethyl sulfinate by SO2 [20], HCl carving the surface of ZnGA [21], Lewis acid (MCln) treatment [22], etc. These studies suggest that the slight increase in catalyst performance may be due to an increase in the number of active centers. However, the surface composition and internal structure of such heterogeneous catalysts are typically unknown, making it challenging to determine the active site of the heterogeneous catalysts and make significant improvements. It has been found that cyanide is effective in increasing the catalytic performance of ZnGA. Recently, Yang et al. reported a high yield of 855 g poly/g cat for CO2/PO copolymerization using 2D-ZnGA treated with H3[Co(CN)6] [23]. Similar structures and compositions exist between DMC catalysts and H3[Co(CN)6]. The Zn-Co DMC catalyst has the advantages of low cost and easy product separation. DMC has been widely used in the synthesis of polyols/polyether, suggesting that DMC can facilitate the ring opening of PO [24]. The catalytic yield of Zn-Co DMC reached as high as 60,600 g poly/g cat after 10 h when the low-molecular-weight polyether polyol initiator was not used [12]. Wang et al. used a combination of DMC and rare earth ternary catalysts to obtain polycarbonate with a carbonate unit (CU) content ranging from 57.8 % to 97.1 % and Mn = 1 × 105 g/mol [25]. It is possible that the incorporation of a portion of DMC into ZnGA could increase the rate of PO ring opening and further improve the efficiency of the copolymerization reaction. Herein, effect of the different zinc sources and effect of the amount of DMC on catalytic process were systematically investigated. First, ZnGA and H2O-activated ZnGA were prepared from two different zinc sources (ZnO and ZnAc2). Then, the effect of H2O on the ZnGA catalyst was investigated by XRD, SEM, EDS, FTIR, and XPS characterizations. The catalytic performance between ZnGA and H2O-activated ZnGA was compared. Finally, the DMC-modified ZnGA heterogeneous catalyst was studied and the optimal reaction conditions for CO2/PO copolymerization was revealed (Scheme 1 ). 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials ZnO (≥ 99.8 %, anhydrous) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (China) Co., Ltd.; ZnAc2 (≥ 99 %, anhydrous) was purchased from Shanghai Mayer Chemical Technology Co., Ltd.; GA (≥ 99 %, anhydrous) was purchased from Shanghai Titan Technology Co., Ltd.; Zinc chloride (ZnCl2, ≥ 99 %, anhydrous) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.; Potassium hexacyanocobaltate (K3[Co(CN)6]) (≥ 98 %), toluene, tert‑butyl alcohol (t-BuOH), acetone, analytical grade dichloromethane (CH2Cl2), and deuterated chloroform (CDCl3) (≥ 99.8 %) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.; Nitrogen (N2) (≥ 99.999 %) and CO2 (≥ 99.995 %) were purchased from Air Liquide Co., Ltd. Liquid PO was distilled over calcium hydride (CaH2) and stored under nitrogen (N2). CO2 was used directly without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of Cat 1 and Cat 3 In a 250 mL Schlenk-vessel equipped with a reflux condenser and dean-stark trap, 98.0 mmol of GA and 100.0 mmol of ZnO (ZnO-GA, Cat 1) were suspended in 150 mL of toluene under an inert argon atmosphere. The mixture was heated at 70 °C for 9 h and then allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting precipitate was filtered, washed with excess acetone, and centrifuged at a speed of 5000 rpm. Finally, the product was dried at 80 °C in a vacuum oven. The prepared material was characterized by XRD, IR, and SEM. The same procedure was followed to prepare Cat 3 (ZnAc2-GA) by using anhydrous zinc acetate as the zinc source. 2.3 Preparation of Cat 2 and Cat 4 Cat 2 (ZnO-GA-H2O) was prepared by activation of 50 mmol of Cat 1 in 5 mL mili-Q water overnight in a glass petri dish and thoroughly dried in a vacuum oven at 130 °C for 12 h. The same procedure was followed to prepare Cat 4 (ZnAc2-GA-H2O) by water treatment of Cat 3. 2.4 Preparation of double metal cyanide The double metal cyanide (DMC) catalyst was prepared according to the following procedure. Solution 1 consisted of 6.6 g of K3[Co(CN)6] dissolved in 50 mL of mili-Q water. Solution 2 was obtained by dissolving 40 g of ZnCl2 in a mixture of 100 mL mili-Q water and 100 mL t-BuOH. Solution 1 was slowly added to solution 2 at 35 °C with vigorous stirring, maintaining a drop for 10 s. After the dripping was completed, the reaction was maintained at 35 °C for 2 h under vigorous stirring. The resulting white suspension was redispersed in a solution of t-BuOH and mili-Q water (1: 1 v/v) under vigorous stirring. The precipitate was separated by centrifugation and then washed repeatedly with a mixture of increasing volume ratios of t-BuOH and mili-Q water (6: 4, 7: 3, 8: 2, and 9: 1, respectively). Finally, the precipitate was washed in pure t-BuOH, then filtered and dried under vacuum at 80 °C overnight. The milky DMC powder was obtained with a high yield of over 96 %. 2.5 Preparation of m-Cat 2 and m-Cat 4 m-Cat 2 (ZnO-GA-H2O/DMC) and m-Cat 4 (ZnAc2-GA-H2O/DMC) were prepared by addition of a portion of DMC into Cat 2 and Cat 4, respectively. 5 mmol of DMC and 100 mmol Cat 2 in a given molar ratio were introduced in 150 mL of toluene in a 250 mL round-bottom flask under vigorous stirring at 60 °C for 12 h. The chemical precipitate was then centrifuged and washed several times with 100 mL of acetone. The resulting white suspension was dried in a vacuum oven at 100 °C for 24 h. A fine white powder m-Cat 2a was obtained with a molar ratio of DMC/Cat 2 = 1: 20. The same procedure was followed to prepare m-Cat 2b, m-Cat 2c, m-Cat 2d with a molar ratio of DMC to ZnGA = 1: 10, 1: 5, 1: 1, respectively. By mixing DMC and Cat 4, the same procedure was followed to prepare m-Cat 4a, m-Cat 4b, m-Cat 4c, m-Cat 4d with a molar ratio of DMC to ZnGA = 1: 20, 1: 10, 1: 5, 1: 1, respectively. 2.6 Copolymerization of CO2 and PO Copolymerization experiments were carried out using a 100 mL steel autoclave equipped with mechanical stirring and oil bath heating. A specified amount of catalyst was introduced into the autoclave and sealed. CO2 was then introduced at a controlled rate, followed by opening the carbon dioxide vent valve to purge the vessel. The autoclave was gradually heated to 110 °C over a period of 3 h. Then, the autoclave was cooled to ambient temperature and the CO2 vent valve was closed. The reactor was further evacuated with a vacuum pump (−0.1 MPa) for 1 hour. Next, a certain amount of propylene oxide was injected into the autoclave, and the vessel was heated to the reaction temperature. Subsequently, the reaction started by opening the CO2 inlet valve to achieve the reaction pressure. Upon completion of the reaction, the reactor was cooled to 0 °C and the vent valve was opened again to gradually release the unreacted CO2 from the reactor. The viscous reaction mixture was purified by precipitation in a mixture of 200 mL CH2Cl2 and 200 mL methanol (v/v = 1:1). The final product was then dried under vacuum at 50 °C for 12 h for further characterization. 2.7 Polymer characterizations 1H NMR spectra of the polymers were acquired on a Bruker AVANCE III 400 spectrometer (400 MHz) at 25 °C. The solvent used was chloroform-d (CDCl3). Gel permeation chromatography (GPC) (Waters GPC 1515) with polystyrene as the calibration standard was used to determine the molecular weight and molecular weight distributions (PDI) of the polymers. The glass transition temperature (Tg) of the polymers was determined using a Waters Q200 differential scanning calorimeter (DSC). Under a nitrogen atmosphere, the temperature range of the Waters Q200 DSC was set to −20–100 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) of the polymers was performed using a TGA Q50 analyzer from 20 °C to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of the polymers with potassium bromide tablets was conducted with attenuated total reflection accessories. The number of scans was 32 with scanning resolution of 4 cm−1 and scanning rate of 10,000 Hz. 2.8 Catalyst characterizations Wide-angle X-ray diffraction (XRD) of catalysts were performed using an Ultima IV from Rigaku Corporation. The mean volume diameter, mean area diameter, mean number diameter and external surface area of ZnGA were tested by laser scattering particle size and shape analyzer. Acetone is used to disperse the catalyst particles. The FTIR characterization of the catalysts with potassium bromide tablets was conducted with attenuated total reflection accessories. The number of scans was 32 with scanning resolution of 4 cm−1 and scanning rate of 10,000 Hz. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) manufactured by Thermo Fisher, UK, ESCALAB 250Xi, resolution > 3 μm, was characterized the chemical state of the surface Zn and O species in the prepared catalysts. A monochromatic Al Kα was used as the X-ray source and the vacuum level was kept in the range of 10−9–10−8 torr. The binding energies of the catalyst samples were corrected based on the reference binding energy of C 1s at 284.8 eV. Scanning electron micrographs (SEM) of the catalyst samples were collected on NOVA Nano SEM450 FEI, America microscopy instrument to verify the change in catalyst morphology. Moreover, EDS mapping was also implemented to confirm the location of Zn, C, and O in the ZnGA. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of H2O in the preparation of ZnGA catalyst The efficiency of ZnGA is mainly dominated by the crystallinity, external surface area, and the number of active sites of the ZnGA surface [7,15,26]. Particle size analysis shows that the incorporation of H2O increases the external surface area to 3.9 m2/cc (Table 1 ). In the preparation of ZnGA in toluene, it was observed that the resulting particles exhibited a larger particle size and lower external surface area, indicative of potential agglomeration within the solvent medium. However, upon re-dispersion of the ZnGA particles in water, a notable reduction in particle size and concurrent increase in external surface area were observed. This phenomenon suggests that water treatment effectively mitigated the agglomeration of particles, leading to enhanced surface characteristics. 3.2 XRD characterization The morphological structure of ZnGA including crystallinity, crystal size, and the surface Zn-OH groups [10,13,15,16,18,27]. The higher the crystallinity and crystalline quality, the narrower and sharper the peaks exhibit in XRD. To investigate the structure of ZnGA, XRD patterns of Cat 1, Cat 2, Cat 3, and Cat 4 are compared (Fig. 1 ). The ZnGA XRD data matches with CCDC card No. 166,386. The results indicate that the obtained ZnGA powder has high crystallinity and excellent crystalline quality, which is in good agreement with the experiments by Ree [10], Kim [13], and Ang [28]. These results suggest that the obtained ZnGA is a crystal composed of a monoclinic lattice unit cell, in which all Zn atomic centers are coordinated with the four carboxyl oxygen atoms through four synergistic anti-bridges to form a distorted tetrahedral geometry, resulting in channels. However, the size of the channels is not favorable for diffusion of CO2 or propylene oxide monomer through the channels [10,14]. The catalyst performance is therefore only reflected on the outer surface of the ZnGA particle [16]. Distinct peaks are observed in the θ=10–12 region of Cat 3 and Cat 4, which are related to the presence of residual traces of ZnAc2 or the formation of new crystal planes. Notably, the characteristic peaks associated with ZnAc2, which are typically found in the 1400–1600 cm−1, 600–700 cm−1, and 900–1000 cm−1 regions of infrared spectra (Fig. S2), were not discernible in the spectra of Cat 3 and Cat 4 (Fig. 3). This absence suggests possible changes or interactions within the molecular structure of Cat 3 and Cat 4 that warrant further investigation of the effect of H2O. The crystallinity and crystalline quality of Cat 3 and Cat 4 are improved after water treatment (Table S1). This improvement can be attributed to the fact that ZnGA crystal nucleus-bound H2O molecules grow with a specific shape in H2O, which improves the crystallinity and crystalline quality of ZnGA. In addition, the XRD spectra of Cat 1 and Cat 2 exhibited dissimilarities in comparison to those of Cat 3 and Cat 4. This observation suggests that the origin of zinc introduces an impact on the structural characteristics of the catalyst crystals. 3.3 SEM and EDS characterization SEM images of ZnGA samples prepared under different conditions are shown in Fig. 2 . Compared to the SEM images of ZnGA and H2O-activated ZnGA, the morphological structure of H2O-activated-ZnGA is altered. The incorporation of H2O leads to a remarkable decrease in the dimensions of Cat 1 particles and the number of flaky particles. Furthermore, the flaky particles break up and transform into rod-shaped particles. Cat 3 is composed of oriented, remarkably flat flake particles. The catalyst particles are broken up and transformed into more irregular, finely fragmented particles, improving the catalytic external surface area (Table 1). In addition, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping was utilized to verify the content and distribution of Zn and O in the ZnGA crystals. The EDS mapping results (Fig. S1) show that the O and Zn species are well dispersed in the whole catalyst particle. Compared to Cat 3, Cat 4 with smaller particle size exposed more Zn and O to the surface, which is consistent with the result of the EDS elemental mapping of ZnGA (Table 2 ). The oxygen and zinc ratios of ZnGA after H2O activation increased from 1.4 to 2.7 and from 1.7 to 2.8, respectively, providing reliable evidence for the increase in the number of Zn-OH groups. The original structure of the ZnGA catalyst is not compromised by H2O and shows a more uniform structure. The incorporation of H2O leads to an increased external surface area and the oxygen-to-zinc ratio of the ZnGA catalyst. 3.4 FTIR characterization The characteristic absorption peaks of ZnGA are recognized by using FTIR analysis (Fig. 3 ) [26]. The FTIR spectra of ZnO, ZnAc2, and GA are shown in Fig S2. The COO− antisymmetric stretching at 1405 cm−1 and 1585 cm−1, symmetric stretching at 1537 cm−1 and the absence of peak f at 1699 cm−1 indicate that the carbonyl group (C = O) of GA has been transformed into the zinc carboxylate bond (COO−). In addition, the CH2 scissoring and CH stretching bands are detected at 1447 cm−1 and 2956 cm−1, indicating that GA and ZnO or ZnAc2 are successfully incorporated into ZnGA. The absence of Zn-O stretching vibrations at around 470 cm−1 and the peak of GA at 1699 cm−1 confirms that residual ZnO has been effectively removed after several washes with acetone. This is consistent with the results of Ree [29] and Ang [28]. In contrast to Cat 1 and Cat 3, Cat 2 and Cat 4 exhibited heightened intensity of the peak at 685 cm−1, which suggests a potential increase in the abundance of associated functional groups after water treatment. Such enhancement hints at potential improvements in catalytic performance following the treatment process. The FTIR spectrum shows a broad absorption peak in the range of 3200–3500 cm−1, which serves as evidence for the existence of OH groups at the surface of the catalyst crystals (Fig 3). In addition, no mass loss was found below 390 °C in the TGA analysis of ZnGA, indicating that H2O molecules are present in the catalyst crystals both as bound H2O and as a component of the catalyst crystals (Fig. S3) [30]. 3.5 XPS characterization To further determine the changes of the surface composition of the catalyst, Cat 3 and Cat 4 were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. 4 , after the deconvolution of the XPS spectrum, different types of Zn species were identified on the surface of the ZnGA, as evidenced by showing several characteristic binding energy peaks. The pure ZnX2 (X = F, Cl, Br, and I) shows peaks at 1022.8 eV, 1023.1 eV, 1023.4 eV, and 1023.0 eV and the pure Zn(OH)2 shows peaks at 1022.7 eV, and 531.7 eV, respectively [31]. The peak at ∼1022.1 eV (Fig. 4a) and ∼531.8 eV (Fig. 4b) of the ZnGA catalyst are reasonably attributed to the Zn-OH surface species. This is due to the coordination of the zinc atom of ZnGA with the OH species following the incorporation of H2O into ZnGA. The presence of uncoordinated carboxyl groups on the catalyst surface was detected. Unsaturated zinc metal ions and more hydrocarbon units are present on the outermost surface of the ZnGA catalyst [15]. The Cat 3 and Cat 4 ratios of Zn-OH state species to Zn2+ are 5.3 and 12.6 (Fig. 4a), respectively, indicating that several Zn2+ species have been converted to Zn-OH surface species. The encouraging XPS results indicate that Zn-OH species and the unsaturated zinc metal ions are present on the outermost surface of the ZnGA catalyst [16,17]. The Zn-OH species located at the surface termination of ZnGA catalysts are important in various catalytic systems [32,33]. Xamena et al. [34] had reported that Zn-OH and Zn-O can act as the active species and contribute to the catalytic performance of the reaction. Zn-OH species can activate both CO2 and oxygenated substrates. Two main mechanisms for the formation of the surface active sites have been reported by Low and coworkers [35], including ligand displacement and hydrolysis, as shown in Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) M n + − L n − + H 2 O → M n + − ( O H 2 ) · · · · · · L n − (2) M n + − L n − + H 2 O → M n + − ( OH ) · · · · · · H L n − Under water-saturated conditions, unsaturated Zn2+ acts as a Lewis center coordinating with H2O molecules, leading to the formation of Zn-OH species. The case of CO2 insertion into metal-oxygen bonds [M-OR (R: alkyl or aryl groups)] has been reported elsewhere [16,36,37]. General research and views are that the insertion of CO2 into Zn-OR complexes (R: alkyl or aryl) reacts readily. The active site is the Zn-O moiety, which consists of unsaturated Zn2+ and O resonances of the carboxyl group of GA. The formation of carbonate bonds can be explained in detail as follows: CO2 insertion into the Zn-O bond, and bidentate coordination with Zn2+. It is noteworthy that the mentioned CO2 insertion occurs during the ZnGA-catalyzed CO2/PO copolymerization reaction and not at the initiation stage [16]. Combined with our study, the active species in the starting phase is the Zn-OH group, and this result is confirmed by the experimental data in Table 3 . The OH in the Zn-OH group of the starting species originates from H2O, or other possible polar protonic solvents, such as amines, alcohols, etc. Polar protonic solvents are used to polarize the Zn-O bond, promote the insertion of CO2 and PO, and further improve the efficiency of copolymerization [15]. H2O generated during the preparation of ZnGA from ZnO and GA in toluene promoted the formation of Zn-OH groups. Moreover, the type and amount of polar protonic solvents employed affect the catalytic performance for the preparation of ZnGA. Consequently, the presence of H2O alters the catalyst surface and crystallinity and increases the content of Zn-OH. The difference in performance between Cat 3 and Cat 4 can be attributed to the increase in crystallinity, external surface area, and the increased content of Zn-OH resulting from the incorporation of H2O. In other words, the synergistic effect of the improved catalyst surface, crystallinity, and Zn-OH content played an important role in improving the performance of the ZnGA catalyst by the treatment with H2O. 3.6 The effect of H2O in ZnGA catalyzed CO2/PO copolymerization As shown in Table 3, the increased external surface area of the catalyst results in an increased number of active centers exposed on the outer surface of the ZnGA, thereby further increasing the catalytic yield. Following an experimental condition, the resulting product PPC has a high carbonate unit content (> 92 %), molecular weight (> 1.4 × 105 g/mol), and Tg (> 37 °C). In contrast, there is almost no yield with Cat 3 (Table 3, entry 3), which is prepared under anhydrous and oxygen-free conditions. The ZnGA treated with mili-Q water shows good catalytic yield and product properties, and its catalytic yield is increased to 31 g poly/g cat over a reaction time of 40 h (Table 3, entry 4). These results indicated that the performance of the ZnGA catalyst is closely related to water treatment [15]. Compared to Cat 3, Cat 4 showed increased catalyst performance (trace vs. 31 g poly/g cat), and the molecular weight of PPC increased to 1.4 × 105 g/mol with 92.5 % of the carbonate linkages in the polymer chain. The 1H NMR spectrum of the PPC shows characteristic peaks at 5.0, 4.2, and 1.3 ppm, attributed to the carbonate units, and peaks at 3.2 – 3.8 and 1.2 ppm, attributed to the ether units in the polymer chain (Fig. 5 ). The detailed peak positions are listed in Table S2. These studies will benefit the development of highly reactive catalysts for the production of high molecular weight PPCs with high carbonate linkage content. 3.7 Copolymerization of CO2/PO catalyzed by modified ZnGA catalysts The m-Cat 4b was successfully prepared by adding a portion of Zn-Co DMC into Cat 4, which showed a remarkable performance in producing PPC with a high molecular weight and a high carbonate linkage content. The XRD patterns of Cat 4, DMC, and m-Cat 4b are shown in Fig. 6 . The m-Cat 4b exhibits separate crystalline structure and remarkable characteristic peaks (at 2θ= 12.7, 22.5, 23.0, 13.3, 18.1, etc.), and no effect of the crystallinity and integrality of the composite catalyst is expected, indicating that DMC is well mixed with ZnGA and the crystallographic information of ZnGA is largely inherited by m-Cat 4b. Furthermore, m-Cat 4b exhibited distinctive characteristic peaks at specific positions, notably 466 cm−1, 638 cm−1, 704 cm−1, 835 cm−1, 1405 cm−1, 1447 cm−1, 1537 cm−1, 1585 cm−1, 2193 cm−1, among others. (Fig. 7 ) This observation suggests that m-Cat 4b inherits functional groups from both Cat 4 and DMC, thereby manifesting an independent structural composition. The copolymerization of CO2 and PO over DMC, ZnGA-H2O, and m-ZnGA catalysts is summarized in Table 4 . The use of a Zn-Co DMC catalyst at 70 °C for 8 h showed a catalytic yield up to 4667 g poly/g cat with 21.5 % of carbonate linkages content, 0.7 × 105 g/mol of molecular weight, and a product with a Tg of 4 °C (Table 4, entry 1). In contrast, Cat 4 shows relatively low yield towards PPC with 92.5 % of carbonate linkages content after a reaction time of 40 h (Table 4, entry 2). Interestingly, m-Cat 4b produced PPC with a yield of 1729 g poly/g cat within 24 h at 70 °C and 4 MPa of CO2 (Mn = 2.3 × 105 g /mol, Table 4, entry 8), which is higher than that of the level reported in the literature [7,23,38]. The addition of DMC, which is known for its superior catalytic performance in PO homopolymerization [24,39], was found to significantly enhance the rate of PO activation. Consequently, the higher reactivity of PO facilitated its insertion ahead of CO2 during the copolymerization process, leading to the production of higher molecular weight products. The ether linkages in the PPC copolymers were inevitable when the copolymerization was mediated by m-ZnGA catalysts [23]. Optimizing the ratio of DMC to ZnGA can lead to the formation of highly active catalysts that is suitable for making high molecular weight PPC, while concurrently reducing the content of polyether. As the temperature increased from 70 °C to 80 °C, the yield, carbonate unit, and Mn each decreased, respectively (Table 4, entry 13), indicating that high temperature is unfavorable for CO2 insertion. Excessive or insufficient amount of catalysts can negatively impact the polymerization process and the resulting product (Table 4, entries 8, 11, and 12). The variation of CO2 pressure from 3 to 5 MPa has little effect on yield (Table 4, entries 12, 14, and 15) [40]. The observed decrease in Mn over time accompanied by an increase in PDI suggests the occurrence of a backbiting reaction to yield more cyclic byproduct (Table 4, entries 12, 16, and 17). The m-ZnGA catalysts are obtained by adding a portion of DMC into ZnGA, which showed higher reaction efficiency and good selectivity to carbonate linkages in CO2/PO copolymerization, combining the merits of both ZnGA and DMC catalysts. The reaction time was significantly reduced after the addition of DMC to ZnGA, from 40 h to 24 h. The thermal stability of the polymer was estimated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Fig. S4-S15) and differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) (Fig. S16). These results of copolymerization revealed consistent catalyst performance and product properties in agreement with previous studies [40]. In general, the incorporation of DMC increased the catalytic performance, carbonate linkages content, and PPC molecular weight while showing a slight decrease in conversion. Appropriate incorporation of DMC is beneficial for the production of high molecular weight polymers [41]. Specifically, at a molar ratio of DMC:Cat 4 = 1:20, the catalyst yield was comparatively lower than at other ratios (Table 4, entries 7, 8, 9, and 10). This disparity can be attributed to either the limited amount of DMC or the uneven dispersion of the catalyst within the reaction system as the reaction progressed. The catalyst m-Cat 4b produced PPC with a high carbonate content of 61.2 % (entry 8, Table 4). This catalyst system stands out with respect to the CO2/PO copolymerization systems studied, with respectable Mn values and yield values. 3.8 Characteristics and properties of PPC Fig. 8 shows typical FTIR spectrum of the PPC copolymer, where the characteristic peaks at 1750 cm−1 (C = O), 1250 cm−1 (CO), 1074 cm−1, and 790 cm−1 (the stretching peaks of C-O-C) confirm the alternating copolymerization structure of PPC. The 1H NMR spectra of the PPC produced by the m-ZnGA catalysts are shown in Fig. S17-S35. The distribution of the characteristic peaks in the spectrum is as follows: 1H NMR (CDCl3), δ (ppm) 1.31 (d, 3H; -CH3), 4.17 (m, 2H; -CH2-), 4.97 (m, 1H; -CH-). The ZnGA catalyst has a lower yield in comparison to that of the DMC catalyst. However, it produces PPC with a molecular weight of 1.4 × 105 g/mol PPC, and a carbonate linkage content of 92.5 %. The DMC catalyst is able to produce PPC with a remarkable yield of 4667 g poly/g cat, but the PPC product has a very low Tg due to the increase of polyether unit in the polymer chain. The m-ZnGA catalyst, prepared by adding a portion of DMC catalyst into ZnGA, produced PPC with a high molecular weight of 2.3 × 105 g/mol and a relatively high carbonate linkages of 61.2 %, which retained the characteristics of the PPC products by the ZnGA catalyst and the high yield of the DMC catalyst. In Fig. 9 , the GPC curves show monomodal distributions. The polydispersity indexes (PDI) of the PPC produced by m-Cat 4b are slightly higher than that produced by the DMC catalyst, which is attributed to the characteristic of multicentric copolymerization. The GPC curves of the other samples are shown in Fig. S36-S47. These results show that a portion of DMC (molar ratio= 1: 10) improves the performance of ZnGA and increases the molecular weight of PPC. The PPC product has excellent properties with a high molecular weight (Mn = 2.3 × 105 g/mol) and a reasonably high Tg = 31 °C. The thermal properties of PPC are strongly dependent on the molecular structure and molecular weight of the alternating copolymers. As a result, the m-ZnGA catalyst showed a remarkable performance for the copolymerization of CO2 and PO, which can be attributed to the synergistic effects of the ZnGA catalyst and the DMC catalyst. 4 Conclusions The introduction of H2O improved the external surface area, crystallinity, and the number of active centers of the ZnGA catalyst. XRD, FTIR, SEM, and XPS characterizations confirmed the necessity of H2O in preparation of ZnGA and revealed an increased content of surface Zn-OH species of ZnGA after water treatment. By adding a portion of cyanide into Cat 4, the modified ZnGA (m-Cat 4b) showed an enhanced performance for CO2/PO copolymerization in producing PPC with high yield, high selectivity, and shorter reaction time. Under the specified reaction conditions, the PPC product with a molecular weight of 2.3 × 105 g/mol and a carbonate unit of 61.2 % was obtained with a high yield of 1729 g poly/g cat. The thermal properties of PPC measured by DSC and TGA showed that the alternating copolymer PPC exhibited good thermal stability. coredata.dc:description: Zinc glutarate (ZnGA) is a prominent catalyst for the production of CO2-based poly(propylene carbonate). The original catalysts, ZnO-GA (Cat 1) and ZnAc2-GA (Cat 3), were prepared using ZnO and ZnAc2 as Zn sources, respectively. ZnO-GA-H2O (Cat 2) and ZnAc2-GA-H2O (Cat 4) were prepared by water treatment of Cat 1 and Cat 3, respectively. After water treatment, both Cat 2 and Cat 4 showed enhanced performance for copolymerization of CO2 and propylene oxide. The characterizations demonstrated that H2O is a critical component that not only improves the crystallinity and external surface area of ZnGA, but also increases the number of surface Zn-OH groups. By adding a portion of cyanide, further modification on Cat 4 resulted in a group of ZnAc2-GA-H2O/DMC catalysts (m-Cat 4). The polymerization reached a high yield of 1729 g poly/g Cat and a selectivity of 98.7 % at molar ratio of DMC/ZnGA = 1: 10 (t = 24 h; T = 70 °C; P = 4 MPa). The modified ZnGA/DMC catalyst exhibited remarkable yield and selectivity for the copolymerization of CO2 and propylene oxide to produce high molecular weight alternating copolymers (2.3 × 105 g/mol).
